frame.name: Sounds
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame is concerned with the percepts that vibrations which travel through the air or another medium produce in hearing organs. Sounds are a subtype of sensation. In talking about sounds, speakers often provide information about how the sound was produced. A <fen>Noisy_event</fen> may be mentioned which gives rise to the sound. Alternatively, the sound may be attributed to a <fen>Sound_source</fen>, which is construed as a point source emitting the sound. A further possible specification of what gives rise to the sound is for speakers to talk about two physical entities coming into contact by motion, resulting in either friction or impact.
Although this frame is defined in terms of a phenomenon of objective reality, many instances of the LUs in this frame are metonymic references to purely psychological phenomena due to a strong metaphorical relationship between external and internal reality. Furthermore, many of the LUs in this frame such as chuckle.n or whimper.n require a perceiver's analysis of a sound rather than being purely descriptive.
<ex>I awoke to the <t>clash</t> <fex name="Sound_source">of a jackhammer on concrete</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Noisy_event
FE.definition: <def-root>An event during which sound is produced.</def-root>

FE.name: Sound_source
FE.definition:
<def-root>An entity that is construed as a single point source emitting sound.
<ex>He woke up because of the <t>blare</t> <fex name="Sound_source">of a car horn</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Theme
FE.definition:
<def-root>One of two entities which is construed as moving relative to the other, resulting in either friction or impact. This entity is given greater syntactic prominence--it is either a possessor or an of-complement of the noun phrase head.
<ex>He heard the <t>clang</t> <fex name="Theme">of metal</fex> on metal , and a ricochet whined viciously past his head </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition:
<def-root>An entity construed as stationary on or against which the <fen>Theme</fen> moves, resulting in either friction or impact. This entity is given less grammatical prominence compared to the <fen>Theme</fen> and is usually encoded in a spatial prepositional phrase.
<ex>He heard the <t>clang</t> of metal <fex name="Ground">on metal</fex> , and a ricochet whined viciously past his head .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Themes
FE.definition:
<def-root>Two entities that are both moving against each other, resulting in either friction or impact.
<ex>The sound of voices and the <t>clink</t> <fex name="Themes">of glasses</fex> was like music to her ears </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Location_of_sound_source
FE.definition:
<def-root>The place from which the sound emanates.
<ex>There followed a small silence that was interrupted by a distant <t>clatter</t>of metal <fex name="Location_of_sound_source">from the ward</fex>.</ex>
</def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition:
<def-root>The location at which sound is produced. This FE differs from Location_of_sound_source in that it does not highlight the sound's spreading from its source to the perceiver's location, which is usually indicated by the preposition "from".
<ex>There was a <t>clatter</t> of running feet <fex name="Place">in the street outside</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Internal_cause
FE.definition:
<def-root>The noise-making may be prompted by either some outside phenomenon or occurrence, or by an <fen>Internal_cause</fen>, that is the mental or emotional state of an animate <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
<ex>She checked a <t>giggle</t> <fex name="Internal_cause">of hysteria</fex></ex></def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition:
<def-root>Certain properties of the sound relating to its production, loudness, etc may be of lexicographic interest if they describe properties of a sounds as such: loudly, shrilly, etc.
<ex>The Brigadier had heard the <fex name="Manner">faint</fex> <t>tinkle</t> of sheepbells</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Component_sound
FE.definition: <def-root>The sound percept may be characterized in terms of <fen>Component_sound</fen>s. <ex>The lunch itself was held in a huge room and there was a constant <t>babble</t> <fex name="Component_sound">of noise</fex></ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition: <def-root>Expressions that indicate the loudness of the sound.</def-root>

FE.name: Explanation
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE idntifies the <fex name="Explanation">Explanation</fex> that the <fen>Sound_source</fen> produces the sound. Generally, this is some external stimulus that prompts the <fen>Sound_source</fen> to make noise.</def-root>

FE.name: Path
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Path</fen> along which the sound travels away from the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
<ex>As he opened the throttle, the roar of the BMW's engine bit into the moan and <t>howl</t> of the wind <fex name="Path">across the culvert's mouth</fex></ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: hoest.n
lexUnit.definition: dat je met je keel maakt door een prikkeling van het slijmvlies

lexUnit.name: trompet.n
lexUnit.definition: uit koper met ventielen, dat een doordringende, schetterende toon geeft
